content.body: I was surprised to find out that the `<svg><use>` element is not really specified through fetch or some terms of "navigation". It also does not acknowledging that it is some sort of nested browsing context (or is it not?).

content.body: This is somewhat related to TrustedTypes experiencing bypasses with `<use href="data:...">` and the question whether `data` should make things cross-origin? Discussion is in https://github.com/w3c/webappsec-trusted-types/issues/357 (scroll down)

content.body: freddy: I've not really played with svg:use much, but I think it fetches, parses into a tree, copies the tree, and it inserts it into a shadow root of sorts belonging to the svg:use. It has to use CORS (or be restricted in some way therefore). That also explains why `data:` URLs work I think as it doesn't create an execution environment (although in some ways it might arguably be close).
content.formatted_body: freddy: I've not really played with svg:use much, but I think it fetches, parses into a tree, copies the tree, and it inserts it into a shadow root of sorts belonging to the svg:use. content.body: mh, well scripts have always been loaded across origins (regardless of data), whereas documents loaded in an iframe via `data` do not share the same origin. maybe I don't follow?

content.body: In the sense that this doesn't create a new environment, but executes in the environment that used svg:use.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: In the sense that this doesn't create a new environment, but executes in the environment that used svg:use.

content.body: Yeah, that whole cloning logic via <use> doesn't really make it nested, right? On the one hand, `data:`  should be safe to clone into the document (as per the same-origin policy) in comparison to a hosted foreign origin. But on the other hand, this is a weird primitive for security controls that can't track the origin of, say, event handler attributes after that clone.
content.formatted_body: Yeah, that whole cloning logic via <use> doesn't really make it nested, right? On the one hand, data: should be safe to clone into the document (as per the same-origin policy) in comparison to a hosted foreign origin. But on the other hand, this is a weird primitive for security controls that can't track the origin of, say, event handler attributes after that clone.

On the one hand, `data:`  should be safe to clone into the document (as per the same-origin policy) in comparison to a hosted foreign origin. But on the other hand, this is a weird primitive for security controls that can't track the origin of, say, event handler attributes after that clone.

Yeah, that whole cloning logic via <use> doesn't really make it nested, right? On the one hand, data: should be safe to clone into the document (as per the same-origin policy) in comparison to a hosted foreign origin. But on the other hand, this is a weird primitive for security controls that can't track the origin of, say, event handler attributes after that clone.

content.body: If it was a nested browsing context the "used" scripts would see a document that's different from the svg:use document. That's not the case, right? I agree svg:use is weird.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: If it was a nested browsing context the "used" scripts would see a document that's different from the svg:use document. That's not the case, right? I agree svg:use is weird.

content.body: And yeah, the rough policy we have for `data:` URLs is that if it creates a new authority it's an opaque origin and otherwise they become part of whatever used them.
content.formatted_body: And yeah, the rough policy we have for data: URLs is that if it creates a new authority it's an opaque origin and otherwise they become part of whatever used them.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: And yeah, the rough policy we have for `data:` URLs is that if it creates a new authority it's an opaque origin and otherwise they become part of whatever used them.
And yeah, the rough policy we have for data: URLs is that if it creates a new authority it's an opaque origin and otherwise they become part of whatever used them.

content.body: fixing this with more weirdness is also undesirable. meh! Only thing I could think of would be "disallow data URLs", but that's probably annoying for image-related use cases..
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: fixing this with more weirdness is also undesirable. meh! Only thing I could think of would be "disallow data URLs", but that's probably annoying for image-related use cases..

content.body: yeah and that policy makes sense for usages in images, but cloning a separate document into another is...unprecedented? :)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: yeah and that policy makes sense for usages in images, but cloning a separate document into another is...unprecedented? :)
